questions.question_text_1: Scientists found an alien world where life follows the same central dogma principle. Their DNA consists of 5 different types of nucleotides (and so is their RNA) and amino acids are generated using codons of length 4. Also, due to some chemical structure of the nucleotides, any nucleotide can occur exactly once in a codon. Calculate the maximum number of unique amino acids that be generated. Enter the value as a single integer.
question_texts: Scientists found an alien world where life follows the same central dogma principle. Their DNA consists of 5 different types of nucleotides (and so is their RNA) and amino acids are generated using codons of length 4. Also, due to some chemical structure of the nucleotides, any nucleotide can occur exactly once in a codon. Calculate the maximum number of unique amino acids that be generated. Enter the value as a single integer.

questions.question_text_1: If the amino acid “Leucine (L)” is generated, then what is the probability that the codon encountered starts with “Uracil (U)”? Assume that the different positions of the codon are set to a nucleotide independently and uniformly at random. Round your answer to two decimal digits.

questions.question_text_1: A receptor R receives information about a pathogen and transmits the information to gene G via the following edges.  • R to Y1 with edge probability 0.02. • Y1 to Y2 with edge probability 0.03. • Y2 to Y3 with edge probability 0.06. • Y3 to G with edge probability 0.01.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: In a random coloring of the nodes of the underlying GRN network using 6 colors, what is the probability that this path is colorful? (Random coloring refers to coloring each node in the graph with one of the 6 colors uniformly and independently at random.) Round up the answer to 2 decimal points.
question_texts: In a random coloring of the nodes of the underlying GRN network using 6 colors, what is the probability that this path is colorful? (Random coloring refers to coloring each node in the graph with one of the 6 colors uniformly and independently at random.) Round up the answer to 2 decimal points.

questions.question_text_1: The following reads are found from a genome sequence of some organism.     ATG,CAT, TAG,GAT, TTA,AAT,ATA, AGA, ATC, TGC,GCA     As a biologist, you have to assemble the sequence of the genome from these reads for your project. Answer the given subquestions with respect to the same. Recall that the Hamiltonian path approach is used in an overlap graph and the Eulerian path approach is used in the de Bruijn graph for the genome assembly problem.
question_texts: The following reads are found from a genome sequence of some organism.     ATG,CAT, TAG,GAT, TTA,AAT,ATA, AGA, ATC, TGC,GCA     As a biologist, you have to assemble the sequence of the genome from these reads for your project. Answer the given subquestions with respect to the same. Recall that the Hamiltonian path approach is used in an overlap graph and the Eulerian path approach is used in the de Bruijn graph for the genome assembly problem.

options.option_text: Global alignment involves aligning the entire sequences, while local alignmentinvolves aligning smaller parts/substrings of the sequence.
Alignment problem can be solved using a greedy algorithm approach.
To compute the global alignment between two sequences, free rides (zeroweight edges) are added from the source (0, 0) to every node and from every node to the sink (n, m) in the alignment graph.
The alignment problem can be solved in linear space.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Central Dogma of Molecular Biology**
- **Concepts**: DNA, RNA, codons, amino acids.
- **Principles**: DNA is transcribed into RNA, which is translated into proteins.
- **Equations**:
  - Number of unique codons: \(4^n\) where \(n\) is the length of the codon.
  - For the alien world scenario: \(5 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2 = 120\) (since each nucleotide can occur exactly once in a codon of length 4).

#### 2. **Gene Regulatory Networks (GRN)**
- **Concepts**: Genes, adjacency matrix, regulation.
- **Principles**: Genes can regulate other genes, represented by an adjacency matrix.
- **Equations**:
  - Number of regulators for a gene: Sum of the column in the adjacency matrix corresponding to that gene.

#### 3. **Genome Composition**
- **Concepts**: k-mer, genome string.
- **Principles**: The composition of a genome string refers to all possible substrings of a given length.
- **Equations**:
  - Cardinality of the multi-set \(\text{COMPOSITION}_k(S)\): \( \text{length}(S) - k + 1 \).

#### 4. **Genetic Code and Translation**
- **Concepts**: Codons, amino acids, RNA.
- **Principles**: RNA codons are translated into amino acids based on the genetic code.
- **Equations**:
  - Probability of a codon starting with a specific nucleotide given an amino acid.

#### 5. **Probability and Path Analysis**
- **Concepts**: Edge probability, path probability.
- **Principles**: Probability of information transmission along a path is the product of edge probabilities.
- **Equations**:
  - Path probability: \( P = \prod_{i=1}^{n} P_i \), where \(P_i\) are the edge probabilities.

#### 6. **Logistic Regression**
- **Concepts**: Coefficients, standard error, z-score, p-value.
- **Principles**: Used to predict the probability of a binary outcome.
- **Equations**:
  - Log odds: \( \text{log odds} = \text{constant} + \sum (\text{Coefficient}_i \times \text{Variable}_i) \).

#### 7. **De Bruijn Graph**
- **Concepts**: k-mer, nodes, edges.
- **Principles**: Used in genome assembly to represent overlaps between sequences.
- **Equations**:
  - Number of nodes in a de Bruijn graph: \( |S_{k-1}| \).

#### 8. **Color Coding Algorithm**
- **Concepts**: Node coloring, path detection.
- **Principles**: Increasing the number of colors increases the probability of detecting the best scoring path.
- **Equations**:
  - Probability of a colorful path: \( \frac{6 \times (6-1) \times (6-2) \times (6-3)}{6^4} \).

#### 9. **Sequence Alignment**
- **Concepts**: Global alignment, local alignment, score matrix.
- **Principles**: Aligning sequences to find similarities, using score matrices to evaluate alignments.
- **Equations**:
  - Alignment score: Sum of scores for matches, mismatches, and indels.

### Mermaid Knowledge Graph

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Central Dogma] --> B[DNA]
    A --> C[RNA]
    A --> D[Amino Acids]
    B --> E[Codons]
    C --> E
    E --> F[Translation]
    F --> D

    G[Gene Regulatory Networks] --> H[Genes]
    G --> I[Adjacency Matrix]
    H --> I

    J[Genome Composition] --> K[k-mer]
    J --> L[Genome String]
    K --> M[Composition]

    N[Genetic Code] --> O[Codons]
    N --> P[Amino Acids]
    O --> P

    Q[Probability] --> R[Edge Probability]
    Q --> S[Path Probability]
    R --> S

    T[Logistic Regression] --> U[Coefficients]
    T --> V[Standard Error]
    T --> W[Z-Score]
    T --> X[p-Value]

    Y[De Bruijn Graph] --> Z[k-mer]
    Y --> AA[Nodes]
    Y --> AB[Edges]

    AC[Color Coding Algorithm] --> AD[Node Coloring]
    AC --> AE[Path Detection]

    AF[Sequence Alignment] --> AG[Global Alignment]
    AF --> AH[Local Alignment]
    AF --> AI[Score Matrix]
```

This summary and the knowledge graphs should help you understand the core topics and their relationships for the exam.
